title: Google demos how Pixel 4’s gesture controls work with music, Pokémon, and more
text:
Google has just shown off the Pixel 4’s “Motion Sense” features, demonstrating how you’ll be able to use it to skip tracks, silence calls, and even interact with the pokémon Pikachu, all without laying a finger on the phone. The functionality is powered by Project Soli, a radar-based technology developed by Google. Google advertises that the Pixel 4 is the “first smartphone with a radar sensor” and claims that it has the “fastest secure face unlock on a smartphone.”

Google took the unusual step of announcing gesture support on the Pixel 4 months ahead of the phone’s official launch. At the time, the company showed how it could be used to skip music tracks without having to touch your phone screen, and added in a blog post that it could also snooze alarms and silence phone calls. However, in the time since then, a flood of leaks has revealed more functionality, most notably a Pokémon demo that sees you interact with a virtual creature using gestures.

Motion Sense helps you get things done on your #pixel4 without touching it. Swipe to skip a song, silence a call with a flick of your hand, and unlock your phone super fast with face unlock. #madebygoogle pic.twitter.com/HAIBtBUsxE — Google (@Google) October 15, 2019

Project Soli is the work of Google’s Advanced Technology and Projects (ATAP) team, which has been working on the technology for the past five years. Originally created for use in smartwatches and smart speakers, the feature will now make its debut with the Pixel 4, a smartphone. We were first given a demonstration of the technology way back in 2016 when we saw a smartwatch use it to recognize small hand gestures to cycle through its menus.

However, Soli’s reliance on radar technology means that it needs approval to operate in each country the Pixel 4 launches in. The FCC gave its approval for Google to use the technology in the US at the end of last year, but an earlier rumor suggested the functionality won’t be available on the phone when it launches in other countries including Japan, Mexico, India, Australia, and New Zealand. Google has yet to offer official confirmation of this, but its original Motion Sense announcement video cautioned that the feature “may not be available in all Pixel countries.”

description: Google has just offered an in-depth demonstration of the Pixel 4’s "Motion Sense" gesture controls. The Project Soli-powered feature lets you skip music tracks and interact with Pokémon, without having to touch your device.
